div.head: THE CAMPAIGN..
div.p: A dead calm appears to prevail for the time being in Manchuria, and a telegram from Mukden to-day states that owing to the strength of the respective positions, neither army ap pears inclined to attack, unless possessing such a preponderance in numbers that they are able to make a flanking movement. It will be useful during the present lull in the campaign to study the climatic conditions which must exercise a very large influence upon the course of the war. In Manchuria the climate oscillates between two extremes. In winter the cold experienced is very severe, while in summer the sun shines like a burning copper dise, and the thermometer rises to dearly one hundred degrees

div.head: Sunlight Soap
div.p: Absolutely Pure Genuine. The Great English Laundry Soap

Fahrenheit in the shade. On the other hand, forty-nine below sero, or eighty-one degrees of frost, is the lowest aqtually recorded in Man- churia. Generally, speaking, in the south the average winter minimum is not much below zero Fahrenheit. But what the armies have chiefly to fear is the north wind, which is the terror of Manchi When it blows no cover ing of furs is sufficient to keep out the piercing cold, and life in the open will be almost un- bearable, especially, for men doomed to outpost and sentry work at night. Fortunately, this awful wind rarely lasts three days; and in its absence the winter sun shines 80 brightly that the dry cold is not felt. When once the country becomes ice-bound and the rivers and streams are frozen over, the tactics and even the strategy of the opposing armies will be greatly affected. The side adopting the defensive will find that the rivers have completely disappeared as a calculable factor, and can no longer be reckoned upon as useful tactical obstacles to the passage of an assailant. The lies, therefore, of the Tai-tae, the Sha bo, and the Hun will shortly disappear from the nomenclature of the campaign as the special localities of great struggles. It is a complete transformation of the conditions of warfare, which will bestow a unique interest upon this campaign, already so fruitful in sur prises. Another thing we may look for is a great increase in mobility. As soon as the country roads and tracks have been worn down they acquire the smoothness almost of an asphalt roadway in Alexandria. With the new possibility of moving in all directions without let or hindrance, the scope of the cavalry arm will be greatly enlarged. Accordingly, until April and May next we may be on the lookout for many new features in the winter struggle strugglo between the rival armies.

div.head: CRETE AND GREECE.
div.p: A telegram from London this morning an nounces that Prince George has made another attempt to force the hands of the Powers in regard to Crete. No one acquainted with. Cretan politics can doubt that the union to Greece is bound to come sooner or later; but the moment of its consummation must depend on the goodwill of the four Powers. Turkey would hardly do more than formally protest, for she has practically lost all hold over the island, which has no Turkish garrison, such as the soldiers who represent the Ottoman Suze rainty over Samos. It is thought that France and Russia would not be favourable to union in the near future; the relations between-Italy and Greece are not particularly good, the: Italians and the Greeks are rivals in Epirus, and the compulsory recall of the Italian Minister from Athens last spring did not improve the feelings of the two races: Great Britain has no special interest, in hindering, or in hastening, the union, except that, when once the Greeks have Crete, they will demand-Cyprus, which is always regarded by them as an Hellenic island. The most formidable argument in favour of the union is that no one desires a fresh disturbance in Crete this winter, which would certainly call for the intervention of the Powers Few will be so singuine as to pretend that the Cretans will find amalgama tion with the Greek Kingdom a complete success, nor will the Athenian politicians have an easy task in governing the warlike popula tion of the island. Besides, certain Balkan States will almost certainly pat forward claiek for compensation, as Greece herself did when Hastern Roumelia was united to North Bul garia in 1883. Meanwhile, we cannot shut our, eyes to the fact that the Cretan question has been once more reopened, and that at a time when Europe has many preoccupations elsewhere.

div.head:
THE WAR.
A STALEMATE.
div.p: Owing to the strength of the respective positions, neither army appears inelined to attack unless possessing such a preponderance in numbers that they are able to make a flanking movement. The Japanese probably have the most available troops (Reuter.)

div.head:
NORTH SEA ENQUIRY.
RESPONSIBLE OFFICER ARRIVES.

div.p: stated that, at the request of Great Britain and Rassis, the Emperor of Austris will nominate the fifth member of the Com mission of Inquiry.

It is stated here that, at the request, of Great Britain, the Russian officer, of the transport Kamchatka, who first gave the order to open fire on the trawlers, has been landed! at Dakar. He will appear before the Commis sion of Inquiry. (Reuter)

div.head:
GENERAL NEWS.
A RUSSIAN RUSE. DESTROYER BOUGHT IN ENGLAND.
div.p: The Standard says that Messrs. Yarrow reported to the Admiralty last September that a destroyer had been bought from them by a gentlems in Paris, who wished to have it altered for yachting purposes. The Admiralty communicated with the Foreign Office, who made inquiries in Paris. Their suspicions being aroused, they sent Messrs. Yarrow instructions to retain the boat. It was, however, too late to do this, as the destroyer had left the Thames. It eventually reached Libnu, and joined the Baltic Fleet. (Reuter)

div.head:
MACEDORIA.
EFFECT OF REFORM SCHEME
div.p: According to an official statement issued here, the Austro-Russian reform scheme has greatly improved the general condition of Macedonia. The population itself desires ponce.

div.head:
CRETE.
CERTAINTY OF DISORDERS.
div.p: Cin a memorandum by Prince George, handed to the Powers, he emphasizes the certainty of disceders in Crete, if the people's spirations for the union to Greece are again rejected.

div.head: GREAT GALE IN NORTH SEA PORTUGUESE ROYALTIES SNOWED UP.
div.p: A great gale is raging in the North Sea There are several wrecks with loss of life Blinding snowstorms are taking place in the North and Midlands of England. The tele graphs are broken, and the trains delayed. The King and Queen of Portugal were snowed up at Chatsworth, where they are the guests of the Duke of Devonshire. (Reuter.)

div.head: FRENCH CHAMBER
div.p: The Chanrber of Deputies has rejected the ppression of secret funds
M. Combes had put the question of con fidence (Havas.)

div.head: STRIKE AT LORIENT
div.p: The workmen at the powder factories have declared a general strike, and the workmen at Bret areal are joining with them (Hans)
DIRECT IMPORTER OF BRITISH AND IRISH
JUST ARRIVED LATEST DEMONS IN LADIES'

div.head: THE GREEK ASIZE COURT
div.p: at Alexandria will begin its sittings on the 13th December

div.head: THE BRINDISI MAIL
div.p: will be distributed at the G.P.O, Alexandria, to-morrow morning at 8 o'clock.

div.head: MARIOUT RAILWAY-
div.p: The Dairs Khasss has bought a large quantity of old material from the Railway Administration for use on the Mariout line.

div.head: REUNION DES FAMILLES.
div.p: The series of win- ter reunions of this society will commence on Saturday, 17th December, with a ball and Xmas Tree. Subsequent balls will be given on January 21, February 25, and April 1 respect ively, the last closing the season.

div.head: THE EVENING EXPRESS.
div.p: In response to a petition presented by the inhabitants of Ram- leh to the State Railway Administration, the latter have arranged to stop the evening ex- press train from Cairo at Sidi Gaber, com- mencing from the 19th inst.

div.head: THE FRERES CASE-
div.p: The appeal of M.Yayon against the judgment of the French Consular Tribunal at Cairo, which condemned him to a month's imprisonment for defaming the Con gregation of the Frères, will be heard by the Aix Court of Appeal on January 26:

div.head: BLIND SCHOOLS-
div.p: A 'bazaar in aid of the blind schools at Alexandria and Tantah will be held at the residence of Mrs. Coventry (which has been kindly lent for the purpose), Mansoursh, on Friday next, at 2 p.m. The sale is under the patronage of Mrs. B. Dale.

div.head: EGYPTIAN POSTAL ADMINISTRATION-
div.p: It has been announced by some of our contemporaries that Douglas Morice Bey has been appointed] director of the Port Said Post Office in succes- sion to Mr. Mancantelli: The appointment has not yet been filled up, but it is vacant, as Mr. Mancantelli has been transferred to Alexandria.

div.head: INSURANCE. -
div.p: The "Fidelitas" Assurance Company of Brussels has authorised Messrs. Alf. G. Buhagiar & Co, of Alexandria, to repre sent it throughout Egypt. This company is one of the leading assurance companies in Belgium, and insures against maritime, fluvial; and fire risks.

div.head: DAIRA SANIEH BONDS.
div.p: The Committee of the London Sotek Exchange has allowed the following security to be quoted in the official list: Egyptian Government, £1,264,820 Daira Sanieh Bonds, 1890 "stämped for exchange," in lien of the same amount of bonds unstamped now quoted.

div.head: THE AMERICAN ANNUAL NATIONAL THANKS GIVING
div.p: will be observed to-morrow (Thursday). In recognition of this anniversary, a service will be held at 11 o'clock to-morrow in the American Mission Church, Cairo, near Shep- heard's Hotel Residents and visitors are cordially invited to participate in this service.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL-
div.p: On the 19th and 20th inst. 33 vessels passed through the Suez Canal. Of these, 24 were British, 2 French, 4 German, 1 Dutch, 1 Austrian, and 1 Portuguese. The transit and passenger dues for the two days amounted to 884,032.02 fra. The total transit and passenger dues collected from the 1st to that date on 298 vessels amounted to 6,612,139.09 frs.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive is spending to-day at Mariout, where he is inspecting his estates. His Highness will return to Montazah in the evening.

div.head: EGYPTIAN STATE DOMAIN.
div.p: Messrs, N. M. Rothschild and Sons announce that Egyptian State Domain Mortgage bonds to the amount of £20,220 nominal capital have been drawn for payment at par on December 1. The drawing consists of all bonds (not pre- viously cancelled by the operation of the sinking fund) comprised in the series of numbers advertised

div.head: ELEMENTARY EDUCATION.
div.p: About a thousand children of the employée of the Egyptian Railway Administration are without any means of obtaining any education whatsoever. The Board has now decided in principle to pay a few fikis, who will begin the work of instructing the progeny of platelayers and others.

div.head: YACHTING
div.p: The British turbine yacht Emerald sailed from Alexandria harbour yesterday, bound North The ateam yacht Catarina is now at Port Said, and leaves for Suez in a day or two

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Mose liner Marie arrived at Liverpool- on Monday afternoon.
The Khedivial Mail 8.8. Dabablish will leave Alexandria on Saturday and Port Said on Sunday for Beyrout, Tripoli, Mersins, Alexandretta, Larsen, Limassol, Caiffa, and Jalla.
&HOTEL COMPANY. RIVER-TRANSPORT OF GOODS BETWEEN ALEXANDRIA & CAIRO Three Sailings a-Week.

div.head:
THE BALTIC FLEET.
DEPARTS FOR PORT SAID.
div.p: A division of the Baltic Fleet has left for Port Said. It consists of two battleships, three ernisers, six destroyers, and nine transports
As we go to press, we learn that the Baltic Squadron is expected to arrive at Port Said to morrow morning.
The following are the vessels of which the Russian Squadron is composed:
Battleships: Sissi Veliki and Navaria Cruisers: Almaz and Seietlana.
Torpedo bost destroyers: Blestyachtchy, Bezprechwy, Buistry, Byedoci, Bravi, Bodri, and Buini
Volunteer Fleet steamers: Voronej, Tamboe, Vladimir, Kief, and Jaroslan
Transports Gortchake, Jappiter, Kitai and Meteor

div.head: JAPS AND THE RED SEA..
div.p: If the Japanese are lurking about somewhere in the Red Ses on the look-out for the Russian fleet, the most likely spot for them to be lying in waiting is in the neighbourhood of the Daedalus lighthouse, to the north-east of Berenice. The reefs run out there in every direction and yet one cannot touch bottom in 300 fathome with deep ses lead. The Japanese could place two torpedo-bosts there, one on the east and one on the west of the channel, and they could knock the Russians into a cocked hat at this point.
The Sues correspondent of the Daily Er přess wires to that paper on the 15th inst. as follows:

It is reported that disguised Japanese war vessels have arrived here with the intention of blowing up that portion of the Baltic Boet which will go through the canal. The Russian admiral has cabled to the consulate here to arrange about supplies. Four steamers of the Volunteer fleet which are said to be flying the commercial flag are expected hourly at Port Said. Their names are unknown."

div.head: BRITISH CRUISER AT SUEZ
div.p: As wired to-day, H.M.'s second-class cruiser. For arrived at Suez this morning from the East Indies.
She will change her crew with that brought out by the Hermione, and then return to her station.
It it probable that the Fe will remain at Suer with the Hermione pending the arrival of the Baltic Squadron.

div.head: PUNITIVE EXPEDITION IN SUDAN.
div.p: The War Office issued the following state- ment to the Press yesterday:

On the 10th ult. a patrol left El Obeid for Rahad, under the command of Miralai O'Con- nell Bey, to proceed against Abou Zeids of Kitrs, who had expelled the Mek appointed by the Moudir of Kordofan last April and asurped his authority.

The force arrived at Gebel Daier on October 12, when Abou Zeida was ordered to come in by the 13th. He refused, and on the 14th the axpedition advanced, capturing the village and some hills. Meantime, the Meks of Feria and Kemla joined Abou Zeids and desultory firing continued till the 18th, when the Camel Corps and artillery captured the two villages. In the afternoon of the same day, the Meks of Parla and Kimla came in and received the "Amam." After the last skirmish Abou Zeida, with few followers, took to the hills, but on October 21 he surrendered and received the "Amam." No further trouble is expected in this part of the country. The following was the composi tion of the expeditionary force-
3 guns. Camel Corps-6 officers, 200 N.C.O.'s and

div.head: SOLAR MOTORS FOR EGYPT.
div.p: Egypt is shortly to have what are called "solar motors." The heat of the sun, so long neglected as a practical factor in producing power as applied to industries, is being taken up seriously, and another generation (or our own) will see the land dotted over with devices of one kind or another for gathering and con centrating the heat and power, arriving at the earth from the sun, and heretofore absolutely waited, so far as human utility is concerned. One development of the practical use of solar heat is the solar motor. This is so designed na to automatically face the sun at all times of the day, and by the use of a steam boiler in ita focus, produces steam at a high pressure, and in great quantity, for any use

One of these devices is to-day in actual practical use in Arisons, at Willcox, and is pumping all the water needed for irrigating a very large farm in that arid,country. Others, sopording to a correspondent of the New York Herald (Paris), are being sent to Egypt and South Africa
The greal economic problem solved by the utilisation of the sun's heat is, of course, the practical production of power to say degree without cost of fuel
That this will be developed more and more As the years go by, producing power where fual is absent or its price prohibitive, seems now an unquestionable fact,

div.head:
THE HOUSING PROBLEM.
MR. ALDERSON'S SCHEME
div.p: The following is the text of a proposal which is to be placed before the Alexandria Municipal Commission by Mr. G. B. Alderson on Wednesday next, in regard to the housing question in the city:
"In answer to the locataires plea re more accommodation for artisans and employés, I beg to submit the following suggestions:
"On the table you will find complete plans, with all details, for a block of 110, to cost, say, under L.E. 20,000.
"Also plan of the city, showing the lands at present not used and belonging to the Govern ment and the city.
"Will the Municipality request the Govern ment to cede plot marked A., or rather, say, 30,000 sq. m., on the following conditions:
"1. This block to be built according to plans presented, possibly in about a year.
"2. Apartments to be let at rents not to exceed 10% on actual cost to workmen ap proved, and who will be selected or balloted for, of all nationalities
"3. Capital to bear 6% interest, and no more, balance for a sinking fund, repairs, and administration.
"These houses to be free of all taxes such as water, light, and 2% tenant's tax.
15. Water to be supplied by Municipality
"8. Municipality to guarantee a minimum dividend of 3% on the capital.
"On these terms I will undertake to obtain the necessary capital, build, and when finished hand over to the Municipal Council to admi nistrata

"I have visited the various quarters of the city and the artizans' dwellings, and find it is a real vant to avoid disease and discontent. "P.S. The expenses of finding the capital for the first block, till finished and handed over to Council, will be my affair.
"Shares will be disposed of, say, £1 to £28 to industrious artizans and £500 the limit one to hold
"It is my desire to create a profitable and sure investment for the artizans

div.head: IRRIGATION DEPARTMENT.
div.p: Mr. K. George Veitch Murray is appointed surveyor of contracts of the 3rd class and is attached to the service of the Assiout Barrage Mr. G. Parker is appointed surveyor of contracts to the 3rd Circle, Mr. L. R. Wallace to the 2nd Circle, and Mr. F.B. Jacomb to the 4th Circle.
The salaries of each of these officials will amount to L.E. 240 per annum. The Govern ment reserves the right of transferring them, should it seem fit, to the Sudan.

div.head: P. W. D. CONTRACTS
div.p: The Ministry of Public Works has given out the contracts for the winter cleansing works in the canals as follows:-
Galioabieh.-1 and II. groups, Khalil Chahin. Dakahlieh-Group 1., Messrs. Bellini; 2. 8. Chaker; 3. Moh. Ali Wanis.

Minieh (West of the Nile)-MM. Th. Yanni and B. Hanna; Minich (East of the Nile), J. Chasseand; Samalout, W. Papadopoulo; Beni Maar, W. Taylor; Fashn, D. A. Andenis. Beni Sooef-Beba, MM. Liotto and Wour lich; Beni Souef and Wasta, Mr. E. Bramall. Fayoum, Moh. Aff.

div.head: ABBAS HELMY THEATRE
div.p: The second performance of Thomas's Mignon last evening, proved again a very great saccess, Signa, Baldini and Signor Tomisani being frantically applanded throughout the evening. Signa. Baldini a interpretation of the title role was one deserving of the highest commends tion, and the many present. who were moved even to tears by her pathetic impersonation of Mignon, is proof of the excellence of this very accomplished lady's performance. As Gugliel mo, Signor Tomisani, who possesses a voion of good timbre and delightful freshness, was eminently successful, and his delicate handling of the several charming romances falling to his lot, brought him enthusiastic applause Indeed, it is difficult to understand why this theatre is not crowded to overflowing every evening, when two such artistes as those above mentioned are included in the caste

This evening, Rossini's opera Il Barbiere-di Siviglia will be given, with the tenor Tomisani in the caste. To-morrow evening, a benefit performance of the ever popular Ada will be given for a very deserving object, vis, the International Employés Society of Alexandria The performance is placed under the patronage of M. Pierre Girard, French Consul, and the two celebrated prime donne, Signe. Popovici and Fabbri, will take part

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE
div.p: Un Ballo in Maschera was succesfully given yesterday evening. Tonight, Rigoletto, will be given, with the tenor Apostolon.
Tomorrow Cavalleria Rusticana and I Paplincci will be staged, and on Friday Verdi's Simon Boccanegra will be produced for the first time in Egypt

div.head:
ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK.
YESTERDAY'S MEETING.
div.p: The annual general meeting of the Anglo- Egyptian Bank (Limited) was held this after noon. The report and balance sheet were passed, and the dividend of 15% declared which, includ ing the dividend of 10% for the first six months, made a dividend of 13 per cent on the twelve months' working.

The Chairman, in the course of his speech, gave some details as to the issue of the 20,000 new shares. The shareholders took up the quota to which they were entitled to the extent of 18,000; the remaining 2,000 were sold on the Stock Exchange at £12 each nett to the bank, or £2 premium on the issue price, giving the bank a profit of £4,000. From this must be deducted £1,000, the cost of issue (mostly Government stamps), leaving a nett profit of £3,000. This £3,000 is to be devoted to paying the staff a bonus of 10 per cent. on their salaries for the past year. This decision met with the hearty approval of those presant

The Chairman then went on to state that the capital of the bank was one million and a-half, of which half a million is paid up. The reserve fund is also half a million, equal to the paid-up capital. He then sketched the policy of the Board in dealing with the profit. The first charge on the profit will be £62,500,, or 12 per cent. dividend on-the capital of half a million; the second charge, subscription to staff provident fund £1,500; the third charge, the very large amount of £30,000 to establish a pension fund for the benefit of the staff. This is undoubtedly a very large, sum, equal, as it is, to 6 per cent, on the capital of the bank. The £30,000 will become the property of the staff, and the scheme for its appropria- tion to individuals will be carefully drawn up. The chairman then dealt with the general outlines of the pension fund. The meeting ended without any incident, the shareholders prosent expressing their general satisfaction with the prosperous position of the bank's

div.head: NUNGOVICH HOTELS CO.
div.p: In regard. to the various rumours as to the Nungovich Hotels Co., we understand, that Nungovich Bey has not resigned, but that Sir Elwin Palmer, Sir John Rogers and Mr. Cattaoui have sent in their resignations, as members of the Board of that Company.
It is, however, fully expected that the matter will be amicably settled.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Colonel Younghusband, of Lhams fame, and his wife were passengers by the P. & 0. 8. Mongolia, homeward bound from Bombay They disembarked at Suez early on Monday morning
Lady Low also landed at Soes from the same steamer:

Sir Edmund and Lady Lechmere and Mr. Ronald Lechmere are among the passengers by the P. and O. steamer Persia, which is due at Port Said on Tuesday next, Sir Edmund is proceeding to East Africa on another big game shooting expedition.

An interesting party of tourists are arriving in Egypt in a few days' time by the steam ach Vectis, belonging to the P. and O. Steam- ship Company She has on board many well- known passengers, including Sir William J. Dupree, mayor of Portsmouth; Mr. John Gordon, M. P. for Elgin; Mr. B. Dosse, formerly courier to the late Queen Victoria; Mr. J. Lockwood Kipling, father of the well- known author, and also an author himself, having written a charming book on animals; Sir James Pelle, K.C.S.L.; Mr. H. W. Uloth director of the Peninsalar and Oriental Com pany, accompanied by his wife; Mr. Tristram Blis, Mr. C. Martin, Sir Acquin Martin, Mr. G. J. Ingram, with his daughter; Mr. R. E. Craig, Jr, Mr. and Mrs., Flotober, and Mr. B. W. Knox, with his wife and daughter

A marriage has been arranged, and will take place at the end of December, between Adrian, only son of the late Sir Adrian Dingli, G.C.M.G, C.B., Chief Justice of Malta, and Lady Dingli, of 3, Strada Forui, Valetta, and grandson of William Henry Charlton, of Hesleyside, North amberland, and Geraldine, youngest daughter of the late H.F. Curwen, of Workington Hall, Cumberland, and Mrs. Carwen, of The Island, Windermere, and 14, Manson plac, Queen's Gate

The native Press announces the death of Mohamed Bey lakander, son of Soliman Pagha El Franssoni (Colonel Seven), late Minister of War. The deceased was 60 years of age. Dr. Gottheil, profesor at Columbia Univer sity, has left the Carlton Hotel, Balkaley, and is now staying at Shepheard's
Mrs. A. G. Harris left by the Orient-Pacific R. M. S. 8. Ophir for New Zealand on the 17th inst

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Major R. G. Taibet D.SO., ho ar promo- tion joins the 2nd Battalion Rifle Brigade in Egypt, hair worn the "green jacket for party- sixteen years and, earned his decoration as well as the medal with five clasps in Buller's fighting for the relief of Ladywith or Talbot, who is a member of the ancient military and naval family of which the Bal of Shrews- bary is the head, was present at the actions ou Colenso, Vaal Kats, Montecristo, Pieter's Hill, Langs Nek, etc., etc..
Major G. C. L. Stockwell, D.3.0, Highland Light Infantry, has been appointed second-in- command of the 1st Battalion, which lately moyed from Egypt to Bengal,

Major W. A. Boninois, RA, Governor of the province of Bahr el Ghatal, who commands the expedition destined to pazish the entry of cannibalistic propensities known s "Niam-Niama" in the Upper Nile regions, in a very smart officer who has won a fine reputa tion during his six years' connection with the Khedive's Army. He served with distinction in the Nile Expedition of 1899, including the final rout of the Khalifa's forces (mentioned in dopatobe and would have chastised the Niam-Nias early this year had he had suffi cient forces at his disposal.

News from the Mediterranean Fleet states that the first-clas cruiser Aboukir (Captain Sir C. J. Graves Bala Bart, M.V.0) took first place in the recent long-range firing, par ticulars of which were given some time ago in these notes. The battleship Montagu (Captain T. B. 8. Adair) was a good second, Indeed, all the cruisers and battleships shot well.

For a considerable time shorter commissions abroad have been strongly urged on in these notes, both in the interests of the health of the officers and men and the efficiency of our squadrons. The Admiralty has just announced that in the future his Majesty's ships will be commissioned for periods of two years instead of three. This will be a great boon to all ranks, Another important point in that re- pairs will not be allowed to accumulate, As we often the case under the three years rule. The first ship to be commissioned under the new conditions is the first-class cruiser Sutlej, which will be commisioned at Ports mouth on the 19th inst. for service on the China station.

While I am in hearty sympathy with the. appeal of the National Association for the employment of Reserviste and time-expired soldiers; it is much to be feared that the re sponse will prove disappointing. With all the good will in the world, most employers of labour are compelled, by commercial stagna tion, to reduce rather than increase the hum- ber of people in their service, with the result that they are less able than when business is brisk to comply with such appeals But it is an utterly vicious system which makes the Empire's gallant defenders, whether sailors or soldiers dependent on such chances of subsistence after they retire. Yesterday I came across a striking letter from a Time Expired Tommy," illustrating from his own experiences the ingratitude of the State to his class. Of blameless character, and in possession of two war medals with six clasps, be served for a little over thirteen years before passing back into civil life. With. sach an excellent record, he had every right to count on receiving one of the many thou- sands of berths which are in the gift of the State But although he registered his nama both at the Ariy Clothing Stores and the Royal Laboratory nearly three years ago, be is apparently as far as ever from attaining his desire. We are aware, of course, that something has been dose during recent years, especially by the Post Office But if recruiting for the Army is to be extended to classes which now refuse to enlist, as Mr. Arnold-Forster hopes the well-conducted soldier must be secured a reasonably comfortable maintenance after he retires; and that would be effected to a very large degree by giving out fighting men, whether in the Navy or the Army, a preferen tial claim to employment in the lower non- combatant grades of the Civil Service, the Admiralty, and the War Office

div.head: Délégation Municipale
div.p: La Délégation Municipale s'est réanie le 22 novembre 1904 9 h. p.m. soms la présidence de M. Amb. A. Balli."
Priete: MM. E. Benschi, P. Fenderl, Mohamed Bey Said, Mansyur Bey Youssef, E. Bros, Soliman Bey Abani, membres; W. P. Chatsway, administrateur; I. Sedky, secrétaire.

La Délégation désigne dans son sein un sous-comité spécial pour étudier, d'accord avec les services, une règlementation pour. les tramways de la Ville d'Alexandrie, en s'inspirant du règlement édicté par le Gouvernement pour les tramwaye de 1s Ville da Caire.
Un satre sous-comité est chargé d'exa miner les propositions faites par les serviors techniques et sanitaires en vae d'une règlementation sur les constructioni et de lui faire rapport à ce sujet.

La Délégation émt en ce qui la concern) et sous certaines conditions, an avis favo rable à une demande tendant à l'établisse- ment d'an bain de mer à Chatby, son acceptation étant subordonnée aux auto- ristions néosessires à délivrer par to. Gouvernorat

Alderson précissos es proposition pour la construction de maisons à bon marché. L'administration est chargée de pré enter ane notesar cette question.

Williams, ins- peatear da 8me Cercle d'Irrigation, comm deuxiè ne délégué du Gouvernement auprè de la Commission chargée de déciler quels sont les travaux que l'entreprise Almazi sats à exécuter pead ant la période d'en tretien des qusis.
Le Délégation prend note d'ane lettre minatérielle donnant la comp wition de ls Commision chargée des rectisations à faire à le délimitation de la ville
Elle serite l'ordre du jour de la pro- chaide séance de la Commission Maniei. pale qui a réunira mercredi 30 novembre à 9 h. du soir

SCHRAGER Bao CALCUTTA MARKET REPORT FOR WEEK ENDING 10th Novexa, 1904.

Monday and Tuesday were closed days and the Gunny market opened yesterday very" strong, the firmness being due to the rather excited state of the loose Jate market, both here and upcountry, and higher prices have- been paid by Home buyers and spinners for

A good amount of inter bassar business was- put through in Gunnies amongst dealers during The holidays, and with some shippers covering up their requirements prices have further hard and the tendency is still upesifis Almost all consuming centres have been putting in enquiries, such as were for prompt shipment being met as far as possible from second hand holdings, while for forward 'de liveries, mills are quoting very cautiously, and speenlative bolders in some instances bave been unloading on terms most advantageous to themselves. 291

For local requirements fair quantities of E bags have been taken for Jan./April, and with the Crops that will have to be handled, there should be a big consumption of both E bags and 2 lb B Twills for Bombay and the up antry markets Heavy C bags were also largely taken at Rs. 25-8, both by speculators and Burmah skippers, right on to Jute next year, and with the Straits and Far East operating later the tendency is to a higher level of prices

HESSIANS are firmer and do not look like giving way in value. Rs, 12-4 is the nominal quotation for wheat bags, with no sellers, while Rs. 10 has been paid for 40 10 on eloth for Jan./June, and Rs. 7-14 for 40 8 oz. Jan./March and Re: 7-12 April-June. These are the last rates at which business has been done, and mills are reluctant to go on. This and next month's goods are at a premium, more especially nine-porter cloth, and nothing can P be had now at Rs. 8 for Nov./Dec. Eleven-E porter cloth is more easily obtainable in moderate quantities at Rs. 10-4 and Rs. 10 respectively.

FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT) PARIS, November 7. We have taken so kindly to English ways that, for two days this week, we were enjoying Landin particular-almost. The fog was not quite of the yellowish hue that prevails by the banks of the Thames, but it had sufficient sistency-and a sufficient blackness to cause general fighting up at noon. I have just meta French friend, who said, "I have come from London. Do you know-it is astonish ing there was no fog there. The first I saw was at Havre, where the boat had to remain half an hour outside the harbour because of it. The cold and the rain and the fog are the usual heralds of the winter, in Paris. If wish for another sign you have it in the you disconsolate crowd that besieges the doors of the municipal, refuges. It says something for British prosperity that of the fifteen hundred of all nationalities applying for relief last month, only one spoke with the tongue of the Englishman.
